With a Choice Scarf, Magnemite reaches 22 or 21 Speed, allowing it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame. The EVs maximize Magnemite's Special Attack and Speed. A Timid nature is used to outspeed Pokemon with 21 Speed and tie with boosted Scraggy and opposing Magnemite. A Modest nature maximizes Magnemite's damage output. Analytic lets Magnemite hit switch-ins harder, but Sturdy lets Magnemite survive almost any attack from full health.

Usage Tips

Locking Magnemite into an Electric-type move is a bad idea if your opponent has a Ground-type or Chinchou. Magnemite should avoid switching into Knock Off users, such as Pawniard, as losing its Choice Scarf eliminates its revenge killing capability. Use your other teammates to take out opposing Pokemon immune to Electric, thereby allowing Magnemite to gain momentum with Volt Switch more easily.

Team Options

Pokemon with U-turn or Volt Switch such as Mienfoo, Chinchou, Larvesta, Fletchling, and Archen, can maintain momentum and form a VoltTurn core with Magnemite. Magnemite makes good teammates with Fighting-types in general due to its ability to switch into and defeat most Fairy-types. Both Foongus and Cottonee can easily switch into Chinchou and Ground-types, Pokemon that Magnemite struggles against. Diglett is also a great teammate, as it deals with Chinchou, trapping and KOing it with a super effective Earthquake. Entry hazard setters such as Drilbur, Ferroseed, and Archen can help secure specific OHKOs and 2HKOs and break foes' Focus Sash or Sturdy, helping Magnemite clean late game. Magnemite also enjoys having a Pokemon that can keep entry hazards off your side of the field, such as Drilbur, Staryu, Vullaby, or Archen. Pokemon that struggle against Fletchling, such as Mienfoo, Timburr, Croagunk, Foongus, and Cottonee, enjoy Magnemite's presence, as it has little trouble switching into Fletchling and taking any attack it has bar Overheat.

sets.name: Magnet Pull
sets.description:
Moves

Volt Switch is strong and helps Magnemite perform as a slow pivot. Hidden Power Fighting is used to KO Pawniard, Ferroseed, and opposing Magnemite (be wary of Hidden Power Ground) after trapping them, which is the whole point of the set. Flash Cannon is a secondary STAB move with decent neutral coverage. Thunderbolt is a stronger Electric-type STAB move than Volt Switch. Thunder Wave can be used instead to paralyze fast threats such as Abra and Gastly. Toxic wears down Porygon and Chinchou.

Set Details

The given EVs let Magnemite survive a Knock Off followed by a Sucker Punch from Eviolite Pawniard after Stealth Rock, a Brick Break from Life Orb Adamant Pawniard after Stealth Rock, or a Hidden Power Fighting from Life Orb Abra. The Special Attack EVs allow Magnemite to KO standard Eviolite Pawniard most of the time with Hidden Power Fighting. Magnemite uses Magnet Pull to trap Steel-types such as Pawniard, Ferroseed, and opposing Magnemite. Eviolite is used to make Magnemite way bulkier and avoid an OHKO from Life Orb Pawniard's Brick Break. You can run Choice Scarf with 240 SpA / 240 Spe to be less weak to Diglett.

Usage Tips

Use Magnemite as a slow pivot, since its low base Speed plus Volt Switch are really good for this job. Use Magnemite to revenge kill Pawniard; don't switch it in directly. However, you can switch it directly into Ferroseed to trap it. Don't switch into Volt Switch or U-turn if your opponent has Diglett.

Team Options

Fletchling and Vullaby are good teammates because they can use U-turn to bring in Magnemite versus Pawniard, enabling it to trap it with Magnet Pull and KO it with Hidden Power Fighting. Flying-types such as Doduo and Fletchling and Fairies such as Spritzee appreciate Magnemite's help a lot, since its ability to trap Pawniard makes their job way easier. Both Corphish and Omanyte like Magnemite as a partner due to its ability to trap Ferroseed, a big counter to them. Frail Pokemon such as Gastly and Abra appreciate Magnemite's slow Volt Switch to get them into play safely. A Chinchou and Ground-type switch-in such as Snivy helps a lot, since Magnemite is really weak to both. Shellder heavily appreciates Magnemite's help to trap Pawniard and other Steel-types, which are the main checks to it. Entry hazard setters such as Dwebble are a big help, since Magnemite need a bit of damage to KO some variants of Eviolite Pawniard.

Doduo.overview: Doduo is a strange bird; it has amazing 19 Attack and 18 Speed stats and Brave Bird, which makes it a solid wallbreaker in Little Cup. However, it has an average ability, no reliable coverage moves at all, and low defenses. In comparison, Fletchling finds it easier to sweep thanks to Gale Wings and Toxic Orb + Guts Taillow is much stronger and faster. However, Doduo still has some advantages over them. It is stronger than Fletchling, a tad bulkier than Taillow, and can use the more reliable Life Orb. Access to Knock Off distinguishes Doduo from Taillow and Fletchling, giving it more chances to support the team. It also has access to tools like Pursuit and Quick Attack. Overall, though it is walled by several top threats and easily taken out by Pawniard, Doduo should not be underestimated; with the right support, it can be a deadly wallbreaker and revenge killer.
Doduo.comments:
Other Options

A set with the only Attack-boosting move Doduo learns, Work Up, can be used with Hidden Power. However, Doduo's frailty makes it very hard to set up. A Focus Sash set with Flail (or Endeavor) + Quick Attack can also be used, but usually only works once, and needs a lot of support from your team. Drill Peck can be used when you want to avoid recoil. Double Hit breaks Substitute, Focus Sash, and Sturdy but it is much weaker than Double-Edge or Return. Roost can be used on the Life Orb set for recovering recoil or Stealth Rock damage. Steel Wing is a guaranteed 2HKO on defensive Archen with Life Orb.

Checks and Counters

Steel-types: Doduo can't do anything to Steel-types; they are all bulky, resist its STAB moves, and can even set up on Doduo. Pawniard easily KOs Doduo with some prediction.

Rock-types: Rock-types resist both of Doduo's STAB moves and have a STAB super effective move to KO Doduo with. A very dangerous counter is Tirtouga, which can easily set up Shell Smash/Stealth Rock while walling Doduo.

Electric-types: Most Electric-types are too frail to act as a counter to Doduo, but they can still check it easily with their STAB moves.

Strong Physical Walls: Physical walls can sponge anything Doduo throws at them, especially if they have recovering moves. For instance, Hippopotas can KO it with Rock Slide or just stall with Slack Off until recoil KOes Doduo.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
Moves

Brave Bird is an obligatory STAB move that smashes anything which doesn't resist it, especially top threats such as Scraggy, Cottonee, and Mienfoo; even walls that don't resist it are 2HKOed, such as Porygon. Knock Off is used for supporting the team and it 2HKOes standard Slowpoke. Quick Attack is an important way to revenge kill threats such as Fletchling, Croagunk, and Timburr without fearing their priority moves; after an opposing Pokemon switches into Doduo and takes Brave Bird damage, Quick Attack lets Doduo KO it before it can act the next turn. Hidden Power Fighting is basically for KOing Pawniard, but it also does solid damage to Magnemite. Return is a secondary STAB option for hitting Electric-types such as Chinchou.

Set Details

The EV spread is used for always hitting hard and fast. Jolly gives Doduo an above-average Speed tier. Naive is used with Hidden Power Fighting. Early Bird is the best of Doduo's three abilities; it can be useful for waking up early in case Doduo switches into a sleep-inducing move, like Foongus's Spore. Life Orb allows Doduo to act as a wallbreaker.

Usage Tips

Avoid switching in Doduo if you aren't sure if it will be into a Ghost- or Ground-type move. Use Doduo late-game when its counters are already KOed or to revenge kill something weak to Brave Bird as most Pokemon can't easily switch into Doduo's Brave Bird late-game. Volt Switch and U-turn are safe ways to bring Doduo into battle. Spam Knock Off early-game so Doduo's offensive teammates may have an easier time sweeping.

Team Options

Chinchou forms a very good core with Doduo; it can safely bring Doduo into battle with Volt Switch. Drilbur is another good partner as it can both set up Stealth Rock and use Rapid Spin. Drilbur KOes Rock- and Steel-types, and Chinchou KOes Rock-types too. Doduo KOes both Drilbur's and Chinchou's counters, especially Grass-types. In general, Doduo can form very good offensive cores with Pokemon weak to Fighting-types, like Pawniard; Pawniard supports Doduo by Knocking Off opposing Eviolites. Finally, Doduo forms another good offensive core with Archen. Archen has access to Defog, and they KO each other's counters. Earthquake breaks the Chinchou + Pawniard core which causes a lot of trouble to Doduo.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Brave Bird and Knock Off are staples. The former smashes through common threats such as Scraggy and Mienfoo and even 2HKOes a lot of threats that don't resist it with its sheer power. Knock Off is a utility option that can 2HKO standard Slowpoke and weaken other opposing walls for Doduo's teammates. Return is a secondary STAB option for hitting Chinchou, but if recoil isn't an issue, you can use Double-Edge. Pursuit is here for revenge killing key opposing Pokemon so that they won't cause you trouble later. Hidden Power Fighting is useful for KOing Pawniard, but it also does solid damage to Magnemite.

Set Details

The EV spread is simple as Doduo's main aim is to hit hard and fast. The main nature on this set is Adamant, as Doduo doesn't have Life Orb for power anymore. Naughty should be used with Hidden Power Fighting. Use Jolly for outspeeding Timid Choice Scarf Chinchou, Jolly Choice Scarf Mienfoo, and Speed tying with Choice Scarf Gastly; while they aren't that common, they can be an issue. Early Bird is still the only reasonable ability choice.

Usage Tips

Use Pursuit against those threats that the opponent will probably switch out such as Abra and Gastly. Note that Pursuit can be used against more than Ghost- and Psychic-type Pokemon. For example, Pursuit can trap any opposing threat that your opponent doesn't want to lose like spinners, clerics, hazard setters, and so on. Again, exercise caution when switching Doduo in; in this regard, take advantage of Doduo's Ghost- and Ground-type immunities. Doduo should be used for revenge killing specific targets such as Choice Scarf Pawniard and +1 Scraggy or Choice Scarf Scraggy. Volt Switch and U-turn are good ways to bring Doduo into battle safely. Use it late-game or to revenge kill.

Team Options

Chinchou makes a great partner, bringing Doduo into battle and KOing some of its counters such as Tirtouga. Drilbur is good to remove and set up Stealth Rock while dealing with Steel-types. This set is better able to deal with Pawniard than the Life Orb one as Choice Scarf Pawniard is currently the most common variant. Cottonee is another good teammate; it can lock the opposing Pokemon into a Ground- or a Ghost-type move so Doduo can come into battle safely. Cottonee easily KOes Tirtouga, a very common Doduo counter. Doduo can form very good offensive cores with Pokemon weak to Fighting-types like Pawniard; Pawniard supports Doduo by Knocking Off opposing Eviolites. Finally, Archen can remove Stealth Rock and break the core of Chinchou + Pawniard.

Seel.overview: While Seel's stats suggest that it'd perform best as a special wall, its general lack of support options leaves it outclassed by other bulky Water-types such as Chinchou. Seel's best niche is as a Perish Trapper, and while the strategy is sometimes regarded as gimmicky, Seel is the best option in Little Cup to pull it off. Seel also has a surprisingly good offensive movepool that includes several priority moves. However, it faces stiff competition from more powerful Water-types such as Carvanha and Corphish. With this in mind, it should be played to its advantages, which include better coverage moves, Fake Out, and higher bulk. Overall, while Seel faces serious competition from other Water-types in Little Cup, it can fill very specific niches that just might fit your team.
Seel.comments:
Other Options

Seel can make use of a few other support options such as Encore, Disable, and Toxic. Ice Shard is another priority option, but it's not terribly useful. Iron Tail can be used to 2HKO Spritzee, but its low accuracy is an issue. A full special attacking set with Surf, Ice Beam, Signal Beam, and Hidden Power Fire is an option, but Seel is heavily outclassed by other special attackers. Finally, Stockpile can be used to boost Seel's defenses, but lack of recovery outside of Rest limits its potential.

Checks and Counters

Mienfoo: Bulky Mienfoo isn't 2HKOed by Waterfall and can recover lost health with Drain Punch and Regenerator. It also has U-turn to escape from the Perish Trapper set.

Bulky Grass-types: Bulky Grass-types can easily switch into Seel thanks to their Water resistance. Ferroseed works particularly well because it can punish Seel's contact moves with Iron Barbs, and it only takes neutral damage from Icicle Spear. Cottonee can lock Seel into a non-threatening move with Encore, but should be wary of switching in on Icicle Spear.

Electric-types: While they have trouble switching into Seel's attacks, most notably Drill Run, Electric-types such as Magnemite, Elekid, and Chinchou threaten Seel with their STAB moves and can Volt Switch out of the Perish Trapper set.

sets.name: Perish Trapper
sets.description:
Moves

Whirlpool allows Seel to trap the opposing Pokemon. Perish Song then puts a three turn counter on both Seel and the foe. The other two moves, Rain Dance and Rest, allow Seel to set up rain and return to full health and instantly wake up due to Hydration. Rain Dance can also be used for team support, ensuring Seel isn't dead weight versus hyper offense and VoltTurn teams.

Set Details

A Bold nature and the given EV spread maximize Seel's overall bulk, allowing it to easily trap weaker defensive threats. Hydration lets Seel heal itself with Rest and wake up instantly in the rain. Eviolite maximizes Seel's bulk, but Berry Juice can give Seel more turns to set up and successfully pull off a Perish Trap.

Usage Tips

Seel should execute its moves in a specific order: Whirlpool, followed by Perish Song, Rain Dance, Rest, then switch. This allows it to trap certain defensive threats such as Spritzee, Koffing, and Lickitung and escape unscathed. It's important to note that if Seel switches out before two turns have ended, Whirlpool's trapping effect ends and the foe can switch out. Seel struggles to trap most offensive Pokemon, so it should stick to trapping defensive threats. If you find yourself up against a team where Seel is unable to trap any opposing Pokemon without being 2HKOed, use it as a Rain Dance setter instead and have some teammates ready to take advantage of the rain.

Team Options

Seel is able to both remove walls and provide Rain Dance support, so sweepers that have Swift Swim or are strong Water-types, such as Omanyte, Carvanha, and Anorith, make for good offensive teammates. Fighting-type sweepers such as Scraggy and Timburr are also good teammates, as they appreciate that Seel can remove Spritzee. Finally, Pokemon such as Lickitung and Spritzee can provide cleric support for Seel in the case that it is heavily damaged or asleep from using Rest outside of rain.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
Moves

Fake Out provides chip damage, while Aqua Jet is a second priority move that has good revenge killing potential alongside Fake Out. Waterfall is Seel's strongest physical STAB move and should be used to hit bulkier foes. Drill Run 2HKOes Croagunk and Chinchou, which are two common switch-ins to Seel. Keep in mind that Chinchou can still outspeed and Volt Switch out to a more favorable matchup. Icicle Spear allows Seel to potentially OHKO Grass-types such as Foongus and Cottonee.

Set Details

Life Orb is required to maximize Seel's offensive potential. Thick Fat is a rather lackluster ability considering Seel already resists Fire and Ice, but it's more useful than Seel's other abilities. The given EV spread and an Adamant nature maximize Seel's Attack while also giving it some bulk. Seel doesn't need any Speed investment, although you can run 236 Speed EVs if you want to tie with other 14 Speed Pokemon. HP investment would cause Seel to take 3 damage from Stealth Rock instead of 2, so it should be left alone.

Usage Tips

While Seel's Fake Out is weak compared to other users such as Aipom and Meowth, the Fake Out + Aqua Jet combo serves as a nice tool for revenge killing weakened threats. Seel can even take out certain threats such as Abra and Berry Juice Archen that are at full health while only taking Life Orb recoil in the process. With the defensive investments, Seel is able to tank some powerful attacks with HP to spare for Life Orb recoil, such as Pawniard's Knock Off and Fletchling's Acrobatics, allowing it to hit them with powerful attacks.

Team Options

Fire-types such as Ponyta and Houndour can blast through the bulky Grass-types that trouble Seel. Ponyta in particular can also run Solar Beam to handle bulky Water-types, another problem for Seel. Bulky Grass-types such as Ferroseed and Foongus have excellent type synergy with Seel, easily tanking the Electric- and Grass-type moves that threaten Seel, while also taking on opposing Water-types.

Grimer.overview: For the most part, Grimer's role as a Sticky Hold user is done better by Trubbish, which has access to Recycle, allowing it to recover its Berry Juice, although Grimer has more of an offensive presence and a bit more bulk. Grimer also boasts access to the elemental punches, something Trubbish lacks. If you need a niche check to Spritzee and Pawniard, Grimer may have some use to you.
Grimer.comments:
Other Options

Grimer has a decent physical movepool that includes access to all of the elemental punches, though Fire Punch is generally the best choice. Ice Punch can be useful in hitting Archen and Ground-types harder, but Grimer has no business staying in on them anyway. Grimer can also employ Infestation to trap opponents and give another teammate an easy switch in. Finally, a mono-attack set with Rest, Sleep Talk, Curse, and Poison Jab can be used, but it is too easily walled by Steel-types. Memento can be used to cripple an opponent and help a sweeper such as Pawniard set up. Finally, Toxic can be used to wear down walls more quickly.

Checks and Counters

Ground-types: Ground-types such as Drilbur and Hippopotas resist Gunk Shot and can hit back with a super effective STAB Earthquake.

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Tirtouga, Archen, Omanyte, and Onix resist Gunk Shot, have good defenses, and can attack back with their STAB moves or a Ground-type coverage move.

Faster Psychic-types: Faster Psychic-types, especially Abra, can KO Grimer with their powerful STAB moves. Gothita is unique in that it can trap Grimer thanks to Shadow Tag and KO with a STAB move.

Bulky Pokemon: Bulky Pokemon such as Vullaby, Slowpoke, Shellos, and RestTalk Chinchou can take Grimer's attacks and heal off the damage taken.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description:
Moves

Gunk Shot is Grimer's most powerful attack, severely damaging anything that doesn't resist it. Fire Punch has very good coverage alongside Gunk Shot, mainly targeting Steel-types such as Pawniard, Magnemite, and Ferroseed. Shadow Sneak is helpful for bypassing Grimer's terrible Speed and makes picking off Pokemon such as Gastly easier. Thief can be used in the last moveslot to take a foe's item after Grimer's Berry Juice has been used. Pain Split can be used for the semi-reliable recovery it provides. Keep in mind, however, that Thief's coverage is nearly identical to that of Shadow Sneak.

Set Details

The given EVs and nature guarantee that Grimer can beat most Pawniard variants one-on-one, as it can never be 2HKOed by Pawniard's Knock Off and can always 2HKO with Fire Punch. An Adamant nature is also useful for the higher chance to OHKO Spritzee after Stealth Rock damage. Berry Juice is for recovery and greatly increases Grimer's longevity. Also, if Thief is used, Grimer can steal the foe's item after using its own Berry Juice.

Usage Tips

Grimer is best used as a check to Knock Off-spamming Pokemon such as Mienfoo, Pawniard, and Croagunk. However, Grimer cannot reliably check all forms of Pawniard, as Fire Punch does not always 2HKO Eviolite variants, therefore sometimes making it setup bait for Swords Dance Pawniard. Also, because Grimer is easily worn down due to its lack of recovery, try to use it sparingly.

Team Options

Lickitung makes a good partner for Grimer, as it can spread paralysis, which Grimer appreciates, and provides Wish support to help Grimer stick around for a bit longer. Lickitung can also check specially offensive Pokemon, mainly Psychic- and Ghost-types through its bulk and typing. In turn, Grimer can switch in on Fighting-type attacks aimed at Lickitung. Grimer appreciates Dark- and Flying-types such as Pawniard and Vullaby to switch in on Psychic- and Ground-type attacks, respectively. Finally, because Grimer often has a tough time taking on Ghost- and Psychic-types, Pursuit support from Pokemon such as Pawniard is appreciated.

Shellder.overview: Despite its below average stats and a common typing, Shellder has managed to carve itself a notable niche in the metagame. Thanks to Skill Link, several of its moves have essentially 125 Base Power as they always hit five times. Also, its access to the coveted Shell Smash gives Shellder the ability to significantly boost its Attack and Speed, allowing it to threaten a good portion of the metagame. However, several glaring weaknesses inhibit Shellder. It relies too much on boosts, meaning that it either has to use a turn to set up or run a Choice Scarf and lock itself into a move, both of which can be a detriment to Shellder's sweep. Also, Shell Smash lowers Shellder's defenses, leaving it even more vulnerable to priority attacks. Its typing and horrible Special Defense stat also leave it vulnerable to most Electric-type Pokemon, like Magnemite and Chinchou.
Shellder.comments:
Other Options

Shellder can run Substitute on the Shell Smash set to help it avoid the revenge kill, but suffers from the loss of a moveslot. A mixed Shell Smash set with Hydro Pump or a Hidden Power is feasible, but outclassed by Shell Smash users with more Special Attack, such as Omanyte and Tirtouga.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types: Most Fighting-types have the bulk to survive an Icicle Spear or Rock Blast. They can then heal their HP back up with Drain Punch while dealing significant damage to Shellder in the process.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Magnemite and Chinchou resist Icicle Spear and the former also resists Rock Blast. They can then OHKO back with a STAB Thunderbolt or Volt Switch.

Steel-types: Unless Shellder has Razor Shell, most Steel-type Pokemon will resist every one of its moves. Additionally, most Steel-types have high Defense, allowing them to wall Shellder even more effectively.

Status Moves: Will-O-Wisp and Thunder Wave inhibit Shellder's sweeping ability by lowering its Attack and Speed, respectively. They can be used during Shell Smash Shellder's obligatory setup turn.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

Shell Smash can be used to boost Shellder's offensive capabilities and bypass its would-be counters. Rock Blast benefits from Skill Link and deals with Flying- and Fire-type threats, such as Archen and Wild Charge Ponyta, while also landing a neutral hit on Water-type Pokemon so they don't wall it completely. Icicle Spear takes advantage of Skill Link while hitting Grass-types and giving excellent neutral coverage. Ice Shard is useful for additional priority, namely hitting Fletchling and Cottonee after it has set up, but Razor Shell can heavily damage Magnemite and Honedge. Hidden Power Fighting can be run to lure Pawniard and Magnemite, in which case the EVs should be changed to 36 HP / 156 Atk / 80 SpA / 200 Spe to OHKO Pawniard after Shell Smash without significantly reducing bulk.

Set Details

Maximum Attack EVs let Shellder hit as hard as possible. 36 Defense EVs and an Impish nature let Shellder reach 18 Defense, an Eviolite number. An Adamant nature is not needed if Eviolite is used because the damage rolls on Icicle Spear and Rock Blast are generally the same regardless of whether Shellder has 16 or 17 Attack, but it can be used to guarantee the KO on Fletchling with a boosted Ice Shard after Stealth Rock. An Adamant nature is preferred if Life Orb is run, however, as Eviolite numbers are no longer needed. 196 Speed EVs are enough for Shellder to reach 26 Speed after Shell Smash, outspeeding the entire unboosted tier and most common Choice Scarf users. Skill Link is a must, as it causes Rock Blast and Icicle Spear to hit five times every time they're used, significantly increasing Shellder's damage output. Running a Jolly nature is an option, but it's generally better to run Impish, as Shellder will have little trouble outspeeding most things in the metagame after a Shell Smash. Eviolite grants increased Defense and Special Defense before Shell Smash and effectively nullifies the drops afterwards. Life Orb necessitates Memento support for Shellder to set up but noticeably increases Shellder's damage, allowing it to OHKO standard Download Porygon after a Shell Smash boost.

Usage Tips

Once Shellder's counters are weakened or removed, set up Shell Smash on a weaker opponent or a predicted switch. From there, it's only a matter of choosing the right move to dominate your enemy. Shellder can bypass Focus Sash users and some Sturdy users with its multiple-hit moves, making it an asset to teams that have trouble with Pokemon like Dwebble or Focus Sash Abra. Due to its outstanding physical defense, Shellder finds it easy to set up on many physical attackers such as Mienfoo, Drilbur, and Archen.

Team Options

If Shellder chooses not to run Razor Shell, Steel-types can be a problem. Magnemite and Diglett are good teammates for trapping and KOing these Pokemon. Knock Off support can aid Shellder in weakening bulky Fighting-types and other physical walls such as Spritzee. Hazard support is greatly appreciated to break Sturdy on the likes of Magnemite. Pursuit support from Pawniard or Cranidos helps to remove Fletchling if Shellder is not running Ice Shard. Memento support from the likes of Cottonee or Diglett allows Shellder to set up more easily; this is especially important for Life Orb Shellder due to its low bulk.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Moves

Icicle Spear and Rock Blast are both powerful moves that benefit from Skill Link and provide coverage against most of the metagame. Icicle Spear lets Shellder deal with Grass-type Pokemon that threaten it, while Rock Blast helps it beat Fire-types and land neutral hits against Water-types. Razor Shell is an important STAB move that can help Shellder get through Steel-types, which otherwise wall it. Ice Shard lets Shellder deal with Fletchling before it can seriously damage or KO Shellder. It also lets Shellder damage Cottonee before it uses its Prankster moves.

Set Details

Maximum Speed EVs and a Jolly nature are required to hit 14 Speed and outspeed the rest of the metagame after the Choice Scarf boost. Some of the remaining EVs go into maximizing Attack, and the rest go into HP and Defense in order to increase bulk. Choice Scarf is a given, as it boosts Shellder's Speed and bolsters its sweeping potential.

Usage Tips

This Shellder should be used as a revenge killer, interrupting opposing momentum and shutting down opposing threats. Thanks to Icicle Spear and Rock Blast, Shellder can bypass Sturdy and Focus Sash and check offensive Pokemon through a Substitute, making it even more potent. It can also operate as a fairly strong late-game cleaner, taking advantage of the fact that most of the opponent's Pokemon are weakened.

Team Options

Shellder fits in well with Pokemon that can take hits for it after it revenge kills something. Chinchou and Magnemite can easily survive Electric-type attacks. As a bonus, Magnemite can also take Grass-type attacks, making it an excellent partner. Fighting-types tend to be bulky enough to take Icicle Spear multiple times and can thus wall Shellder. As such, a Fighting-type counter such as Trubbish can be used to switch into them and bring them down.

sets.name: Bulky Rapid Spin
sets.description:
Moves

Rapid Spin is a handy and fairly uncommon support move that Shellder is a particularly effective user of because, unlike most other spinners, it can threaten Pumpkaboo, the tier's premier spinblocker. Icicle Spear is what differentiates Shellder from other spinners; its strength stems from how damage rolls work at level 5. Razor Shell hits Steel-type switch-ins and carries a useful 50% chance to lower the target's Defense. Rock Blast provides neutral coverage against various Water-type switch-ins, and also benefits from LC's damage rolls, packing enough power to 2HKO Skrelp and Staryu after Stealth Rock damage. However, either Razor Shell or Rock Blast can be replaced by Ice Shard, which is useful just as a priority move, although it is quite weak. Hidden Power Fighting is an alternative option that hits Pawniard and, to a lesser extent, Magnemite hard, but it is of no use otherwise; when using it, the EV spread must be changed to 116 HP / 76 Atk / 120 Def / 80 SpD / 40 Spe, to accommodate for the reduced IVs.

Set Details

The given EVs grant Shellder enough physical bulk to avoid the 2HKO from Fletchling's Acrobatics after switching into Stealth Rock twice and to survive up to 10 normal hits from standard Pumpkaboo-XL's Bullet Seed from full health. The Special Defense investment lets Shellder almost always withstand Life Orb Gastly's Sludge Bomb after switching into Stealth Rock once. A Jolly nature and 36 Speed EVs let Shellder outpace standard Pumpkaboo-XL; Hidden Power Fighting, if you choose to run it, 2HKOes Eviolite Pawniard regardless of Shellder's Jolly nature. Eviolite grants Shellder some much-appreciated immediate bulk to avoid OHKOs from special attackers especially. Skill Link benefits both Icicle Spear and Rock Blast by making them always hit five times. An EV spread of 116 HP / 120 Def / 80 SpA / 160 SpD with a Brave nature can be used alongside Hidden Power Fighting or Scald, but this makes it easier for Pumpkaboo-XL to deter Shellder's Rapid Spin.

Usage Tips

Shellder can usually utilize Rapid Spin without much trouble, as most Ghost-types are unlikely to switch in to block it, fearing Icicle Spear; if they come in anyway, Shellder can easily take them out. However, this does not apply to Frillish and Honedge, which must be worn down with Rock Blast and Razor Shell, respectively, as well as by the rest of your team. If entry hazards do not need to be removed, Shellder still functions as a solid tank thanks to its good bulk and high damage output. Be wary of using Razor Shell if the opponent has a Pawniard, as the move has a good chance to drop Pawniard's Defense and thus activate Defiant.

Team Options

Pokemon that appreciate entry hazard removal support love having Shellder on their side; Larvesta and Snover are examples of Pokemon that both enjoy a Stealth Rock-free field and have good defensive synergy with Shellder. In general, Shellder is an excellent choice for Fire / Water / Grass cores because it can support the Fire-type of the core with Rapid Spin and is not afraid of Diglett, unlike many other Fletchling checks. Pokemon that can deal with Frillish, Magnemite, and Pawniard, such as Timburr, Hidden Power Fighting Foongus, and Shed Skin Scraggy, make for good teammates. Wish support helps Shellder stick around for longer, although Shellder does not have exceptional synergy with any notable Wish-passers.

Gastly.overview: Gastly is a very powerful special wallbreaker due to its beneficial typing and varied movepool. Its Ghost / Poison typing, in tandem with its ability, gives Gastly an immunity to three attacking types, Spikes, Sticky Web, and resistance to four other types. In addition, Gastly's movepool allows it to perform both offensive and support-oriented roles, although its defensive stats leave much to be desired.
Gastly.comments:
Other Options

A Substitute + Disable set can be quite fun to use, just be sure to use Berry Juice as an item. You should split the leftover 116 EVs between Defense and Special Defense; however, if you're using Hidden Power Fighting over Sludge Bomb, put the EVs into HP. Be sure to have Pokemon that can easily deal with Pawniard, who otherwise beats Gastly without difficulty. You can also use Hypnosis on this set over Disable, which is really good against walls. A Substitute + Pain Split set is also viable on Life Orb Gastly. In this case, Gastly should have as little HP as possible, meaning you should split the 116 EVs between Defense and Special Defense. Gastly can also make use of a Focus Sash set which allows it to survive any hit from full health, allowing it to serve as a one time check to setup sweepers, but Gastly misses the power boost provided by Life Orb, and the prevalence of Stealth Rock limits its effectiveness.

A Venoshock + Hex set with the use of Will-O-Wisp, Toxic, or even Toxic Spikes support can also be used. You can use the same EVs as the Life Orb set, with Venoshock, Hex, Hidden Power Fighting, and either Substitute, Destiny Bond, or even Sucker Punch in the final slot. The item can either be Berry Juice or Life Orb, as both are fantastic options. Thunderbolt and Giga Drain can be used on offensive sets if you would like, but Hidden Power Fighting or Dazzling Gleam are generally superior, and Destiny Bond provides better utility. Icy Wind can also be used on Gastly, but without Gligar around the move has lost its niche. Will-O-Wisp and Hypnosis can be used to surprise your opponents, but given Gastly's extreme frailty, this is better left to bulkier or faster Pokemon. Sucker Punch and Knock Off are also options, but with its mediocre Attack stat, they can easily fall short of being useful. However, with Knock Off on the Life Orb set, you won't need Knock Off support, and Sucker Punch allows Gastly to nail opposing Gastly and Abra before they can hit you. Gastly also has Haze and Clear Smog, but with Gastly's lack of defensive capabilities and Prankster, these should not be used.

Checks and Counters

Chespin: With its Hidden Ability, Bulletproof, Chespin can easily come in on anything Gastly uses, and wall it without a problem. This allows Chespin to reliably set up Spikes and eliminate Gastly with Payback or Rock Slide after they have been set.

Drilbur: With Mold Breaker Earthquake, Drilbur easily threatens Gastly. However, Drilbur will have to be wary, as it is outsped by Gastly and Life Orb Shadow Ball will do quite a lot of damage.

Stunky: Gastly definitely has to be wary of Stunky, who easily switches into any set and threatens to KO Gastly with a Dark-type STAB move, like Pursuit when switching out, or Sucker Punch when attacking.

Pawniard: Pawniard resists both of Gastly's main attacking moves, but Hidden Power Fighting easily beats it. Pawniard has many moves in its arsenal that eliminate Gastly with ease. Its Choice Scarf set can easily come and Pursuit trap Gastly. However, because of Hidden Power Fighting, it will still have to switch in with caution.

Dark-types: Dark-types threaten Gastly easily, as they resist its main STAB move, Shadow Ball, and some, like Houndour, even have access to Sucker Punch and Pursuit. Vullaby and Scraggy are also very threatening due to their ability to live many of Gastly's attacks bar Dazzling Gleam, and then KO it with Knock Off. Vullaby will still have to be very careful of switching in due to Sludge Bomb, which 2HKOes it, and Dazzling Gleam, which is super effective.

Priority: With Gastly's severe frailty, it is easily prone to being KOed by priority attacks from Pawniard, Fletchling, Carvanha, Tirtouga, Stunky, and many other Pokemon. However, thanks to its typing, it is immune to Mach Punch, Vacuum Wave, Fake Out, Feint, and Extreme Speed. Sucker Punch also fails if Gastly uses a non-attacking move.

Bulky Special Walls: Gastly fails to 2HKO Munchlax and Lickitung, and even has trouble with Porygon and Vullaby. Although all of these can also KO Gastly with moves of their own, it is more important to note that they all effectively wall Gastly. Lileep also falls into this category, as it fares just as well against Gastly as the previously mentioned Pokemon; however, it is not immune to Shadow Ball.

Faster Pokemon: If you don't have priority that can hit Gastly, Pokemon who outspeed it can also be a decent answer. Meowth, Aipom, Elekid, Abra, Taillow, and plenty of others give Gastly a hard time. However, many of these checks need to be wary of the Choice Scarf set.

sets.name: Life Orb
sets.description:
Moves

Shadow Ball and Sludge Bomb are both great STAB moves, and the latter has a nifty chance to inflict poison. Hidden Power Fighting helps Gastly to KO Pawniard, but Dazzling Gleam hits Scraggy for large amounts of damage. Substitute allows Gastly to bypass Sucker Punch and eliminate Pawniard switch-ins, though Destiny Bond allows Gastly to take a foe when it dies.

Set Details

200 Special Attack and 200 Speed EVs max out offensive stats when using Hidden Power Fighting. 80 Special Defense keeps Gastly's HP stat at 19, which minimizes both Substitute and Life Orb recoil, and ensures that Porygon's Download gives it a boost in Attack. If Gastly runs Dazzling Gleam over Hidden Power Fighting, an alternate EV spread of 36 Def / 196 SpA / 76 SpD / 196 Spe should be used to give Gastly an extra point in Defense. Life Orb allows Gastly to break down walls with ease.

Usage Tips

Use Gastly the way you would a revenge killer; it is extremely frail, and shouldn't be switching in much. Gastly is very powerful; however, you should avoid being too aggressive. For instance, it won't be OHKOing Pokemon such as defensive Tirtouga or Vullaby. Also, you should be wary of Pokemon with Pursuit when switching out.

Team Options

Porygon is an ideal teammate for Gastly, as it can reliably deal with Abra and other special attackers. Fighting- and Fairy-types enjoy Gastly’s ability to reliably beat Trubbish, which is a threat to them. Fighting-types can help Gastly eliminate bulky Normal- and Dark-types. Cottonee and Vullaby are also great partners as they can both weaken and counter Drilbur. Vullaby also beats Psychic-types that threaten Gastly, although Cottonee gives Gastly a free turn to come in by Encoring a move. Knock Off support is greatly appreciated, as being able to rip through more defensive and bulky threats more easily is always useful. Pokemon with Pursuit are great partners with Gastly as well, as they eliminate Ghost- and Psychic-types.

sets.name: Hex
sets.description:
Moves

Hex is Gastly's primary STAB move. When combined with Will-O-Wisp, it can KO Pokemon such as Drilbur and Mienfoo. Will-O-Wisp also allows Gastly to deal with physical attackers such as Pawniard and Mienfoo, preventing them from KOing Gastly if its Berry Juice is used up. Substitute allows Gastly to activate its Berry Juice faster, get momentum, and force mind games against Sucker Punch users. Sludge Bomb is Gastly's secondary STAB move, allowing it to deal with Fairy-types such as Snubbull and Cottonee. Dazzling Gleam can be used instead of Sludge Bomb; it helps to hit Scraggy, Vullaby, and non-burned Fighting-types. Hidden Power Fighting is another option to hit Pawniard. Disable can be used if your team has trouble against bulky Pokemon such as Porygon and Slowpoke. Destiny Bond lets Gastly take down another Pokemon with it.

Set Details

This set takes advantage of Gastly's speed and good movepool, giving it good offensive presence and a fast Will-O-Wisp, which lets it burn most of its common switch-ins, such as Pawniard and Porygon. The EV spread grants a great deal of Speed and Special Attack to boost its offensive presence. The defensive EVs allow it to better withstand Knock Offs and Drilbur's Earthquake, as well as set up Substitute against Foongus. The Speed investment allows it to outspeed Drilbur, Pawniard, and Mienfoo, as well as Speed tie with opposing Gastly. If more power is needed, Life Orb can be used over Berry Juice, and some of the defensive EVs can be moved to Special Attack. Keep in mind that it will then be harder to stall for Will-O-Wisp with Substitute and that Gastly lacks longevity without Berry Juice, which is detrimental due to its lack of immediate power.

Usage Tips

Use Will-O-Wisp to give Hex more power. Always use Substitute on Foongus to block Spore, as well as to activate Berry Juice if up against an attack that Gastly can only survive from full health, or against slow Knock Off users. Use Gastly the way you would use a wallbreaker; it is not that bulky, so you need to make sure you don't switch it in most of the time. Mienfoo's slow U-turn can be used as a way to get Gastly in safely. Go on the offensive when you know you'll get a KO or at least do a lot of damage. You also need to be wary of Pokemon with Pursuit when you are going to switch Gastly out.

Team Options

Gastly appreciates Toxic Spikes support from Trubbish and Skrelp a lot, since it then does not need to waste a turn using Will-O-Wisp to power up Hex, and besides that, most of the foes Gastly wants to burn are immune to Toxic Spikes. If you have Toxic Spikes support, Venoshock is an option instead of Sludge Bomb. Fighting- and Fairy-types greatly appreciate Gastly's help because it can deal with Poison-types such as Foongus, which is a hard counter to them. In return, the Fighting-types can weaken Knock Off users for Gastly and beat Dark- and Normal-types such as Pawniard and Porygon, which are the main Gastly counters. Any Pokemon with Pursuit like Pawniard, Stunky, or Honedge can help Gastly, since they can trap Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Abra, opposing Gastly, and Pumpkaboo. A switch-in to Fletchling such as Chinchou or Archen is appreciated because Fletchling forces Gastly to switch out. Entry hazard support in general from Pokemon like Dwebble, Trubbish, and Pineco helps Gastly obtain more KOs. Gastly is already a really good spinblocker, but if you really want to keep hazards up, Pawniard can help you there as well by discouraging Defog.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Shadow Ball and Sludge Bomb, which has a good chance to poison targets, are great STAB moves. Hidden Power Fighting nails Pawniard on the switch, while Dazzling Gleam has nice coverage with Shadow Ball, and allows Gastly to eliminate Choice Scarf Scraggy, or Scraggy after it has set up a Dragon Dance. Trick allows Gastly to disrupt walls like Porygon and Vullaby, giving partners such as Scraggy better opportunities to set up. Destiny Bond can be used to beat Pokemon as Gastly faints, allowing it to eliminate a Pokemon who could potentially threaten the rest of your team.

Set Details

200 Special Attack and 200 Speed EVs maximize offensive stats when Hidden Power Fighting is used, while 80 Special Defense EVs ensure that Porygon's Download will raise its Attack stat. If Gastly runs Destiny Bond or Dazzling Gleam over Hidden Power Fighting, an alternate EV spread of 36 Def / 196 SpA / 76 SpD / 196 Spe should be used to give Gastly an extra point in Defense. Choice Scarf allows Gastly to outspeed threats that would normally threaten it, such as Abra and Choice Scarf Pawniard. Modest can be used if you're not using Trick, but if you are, you'll want to have 18 Spe after you lose your Choice Scarf.

Usage Tips

Use Gastly as a revenge killer and don't switch it into attacks. Only Trick away your Choice Scarf when you are certain you won't need it any further.

Team Options

Scraggy is a great partner for Gastly, as it eliminates many threats Gastly doesn't like to have around, including Psychic- and Dark-types. Scraggy also provides Knock Off support, and enjoys being able to set up more efficiently after Gastly has Tricked its Choice Scarf onto a wall. Vullaby is also a great partner for Gastly, as it also provides Knock Off support, allowing Gastly to rip through more defensive threats, and is a great switch-in for Psychic-types, Fighting-types, and Drilbur. Cottonee is also a great partner, as it reliably counters Drilbur, and gives Gastly free turns to come in when it uses Encore. Fighting- and Dark-types also aid in Gastly's performance, the former by eliminating Dark-types, and the latter by eliminating Psychic- and Ghost-types.

Onix.overview: Onix is a niche Pokemon thanks to its unique stats and ability. Due to its Speed, it functions differently from Geodude, as it can Taunt and KO faster Pokemon. This is important when dealing with users of Sticky Web and Shell Smash. Compared to Archen and other Stealth Rock users, Sturdy gives Onix the ability to reliably check a large number of Pokemon, even ones that use super effective moves, such as Magnemite.
Onix.comments:
Other Options

A Curse + Dragon Tail set is an option, but it's outclassed immensely by many other Pokemon. Heavy Slam can be used to hit Fairy-types, while Toxic can wear down bulky switch-ins such as Mienfoo. An offensive set with Rock Polish is a possibility, but Onix lacks the power to be threatening enough after a Speed boost. Stone Edge can be used instead of Rock Blast to hit specific Pokemon such as Archen without triggering Berry Juice, but is less accurate and doesn't bypass Sturdy and Focus Sash. Explosion can be used in a last-ditch effort to KO a Rapid Spin or Defog user, but again, its utility is hampered by Onix's low Attack stat.

Checks and Counters

Multi-Hit Moves: Onix has the most trouble with certain setup sweepers, such as Shellder, that can outpace it or have multi-hit moves. Though Taunt prevents Shellder from setting up, it is a major threat to Onix because it can bypass Sturdy with Icicle Spear.

Bulky Fighting-types: Onix has a very low Attack stat, so any bulky Fighting-type can switch into Earthquake and recover any lost HP with Drain Punch.

Bulky Grass-types: Similar to Fighting-types, Grass-types can break Onix easily while healing themselves of any Earthquake or Rock Blast damage with Giga Drain.

Drilbur: Drilbur is very good at countering Onix due its access to Rapid Spin and Mold Breaker allowing it to KO through Sturdy.

sets.name: Sturdy + Berry Juice
sets.description:
Moves

Earthquake is Onix's main STAB attack. Rock Blast is a very useful secondary STAB attack to deal with opposing Sturdy Pokemon as well as Substitute users such as Torchic. Stealth Rock is one of the main reasons to use Onix. Thanks to its high Defense and Sturdy ability, Onix usually has time to both set up Stealth Rock and damage or Taunt an opponent's setup Pokemon. Taunt makes Onix the perfect counter to Shell Smashers and RestTalkers, and also prevents setup by Dwebble and status moves such as Will-O-Wisp from Vulpix. Roar can force out the Pokemon that Onix isn't fast enough to Taunt or strong enough to KO.

Set Details

The EVs are standard; maximum Speed is to outpace most middling Pokemon such as Dwebble or Tirtouga. Attack is maxed and 76 HP EVs bring Onix to 21 HP, allowing it to recover a full 20 HP from Berry Juice after Sturdy activates. Note that at this Speed, Onix still Speed ties with Timid Surskit.

Usage Tips

Onix has two major ways of influencing a game. If there is a Pokemon that the team needs it to counter, such as Fletchling, it can be kept alive and sent in whenever Fletchling makes an appearance. Alternatively, Onix functions as an exceptional lead due to its ability to beat or damage many Pokemon one-on-one, including common setup leads like Spinark and Dwebble, while still getting Stealth Rock up.

Team Options

Onix works on just about any team in need of a reliable Stealth Rock user. It also has a fast Taunt, so it's quite useful for other Pokemon that rely on Sturdy and Focus Sash, such as Magnemite or Diglett. Onix gets forced out quite easily by Mienfoo after Stealth Rock is set up, so a switch-in such as Trubbish works nicely with it. Trubbish also deals with Grass-types quite well.

Drowzee.overview: Drowzee's niche lies in its fantastic special bulk, which, when combined with its Psychic typing, lets it beat common special attackers such as Abra and Skrelp. A decent ability in Insomnia also makes it a great counter to Foongus. Furthermore, Drowzee has a decent movepool with support and attacking options such as Thunder Wave and Shadow Ball. However, Drowzee is slow, very passive, and weak to the common Knock Off, causing it to lose momentum. In addition, Drowzee is reliant on Wish for recovery, making it more vulnerable to status and taking up an additional moveslot.
Drowzee.comments:
Other Options

Drowzee can make use of its decent physical movepool with options such as Zen Headbutt, Drain Punch, and the elemental punches. However, most of these options are weak coming off of Drowzee's low Attack. Shadow Ball is useful for hitting Abra for much more damage than Psychic, but it is useless outside of that. Due to its low Speed, Drowzee makes for a decent Trick Room setter; however, it is too weak to take advantage of Trick Room itself. Counter hits physical attackers targeting Drowzee's lower Defense. Hypnosis can cripple foes with sleep but is very inaccurate. Finally, Drowzee has access to many setup moves, including Calm Mind, Nasty Plot, and Belly Drum, but it isn't fast enough to use these effectively.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types such as Pawniard and Vullaby are immune to Psychic and can threaten to OHKO Drowzee with their STAB Knock Offs, but they do not like being paralyzed. Scraggy can set up on Drowzee and does not mind Thunder Wave thanks to Shed Skin.

Taunt Users: Taunt users such as Cottonee can completely shut down Drowzee while not taking much from its weak Psychic.

Status: While Drowzee does not particularly mind paralysis, burns and poison can be especially debilitating, since Drowzee's reliance on Wish for recovery makes the passive damage add up quickly.

Ghost-types: Ghost-types such as Gastly can force Drowzee out with the threat of a super effective STAB Shadow Ball, but they are crippled by Thunder Wave.

Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Corphish can target Drowzee's average Defense with super effective attacks such as Knock Off.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Moves

Wish allows Drowzee to heal itself or other Pokemon. Protect lets Drowzee scout its foe or safely heal itself with Wish. Psychic is Drowzee's strongest STAB attack, hitting Poison- and Fighting-types such as Skrelp and Mienfoo super effectively. Thunder Wave cripples common switch-ins to Drowzee such as Pawniard.

Set Details

The given EV spread with a Bold nature gives Drowzee 24 / 14 / 18 bulk, hitting Eviolite numbers and letting it pass 12 HP Wishes, with the leftover EVs used to slightly bolster its Special Attack and Speed. Insomnia makes Drowzee immune to sleep-inducing moves, such as Foongus's Spore. Eviolite boosts Drowzee's Defense and Special Defense by 50%.

Usage Tips

Use Drowzee's fantastic special bulk and Insomnia to switch into powerful special attackers such as Abra and Skrelp or into sleep inducers such as Foongus. If you think the opponent will switch to a counter, such as Pawniard, use Thunder Wave to cripple the counter as it switches in. Avoid Knock Off users, as Drowzee will take severe damage from them and lose its Eviolite, which it needs to effectively check the threats it wants to check. Drowzee can be a momentum sink; thus, it is best used on bulkier teams that don't mind the momentum loss it causes.

Team Options

Fairy-types such as Spritzee and Snubbull can absorb Knock Off for Drowzee while Drowzee beats Poison-types for them. Bulky Normal-types such as Munchlax or Pursuit trappers such as Stunky are useful to help beat Ghost-types. Stealth Rock setters such as Pawniard help Drowzee guarantee the 2HKO on Foongus with Psychic.

Krabby.overview: The first things that stick out about Krabby are its exceptionally high Attack and Defense. Its Attack stat is one of the highest in the tier, only falling behind Archen and Cranidos. It also has access to Swords Dance and Agility, two excellent boosting moves that allow Krabby to easily sweep unsuspecting teams with its wide coverage. Some of Krabby's downsides, however, are its low Special Defense and HP, making it unable to go toe to toe with most special attackers. Ferroseed and most other Grass-types in Little Cup can easily switch in on any of Krabby's moves, bar Superpower, and proceed to set up entry hazards or afflict it with a status ailment.
Krabby.comments:
Other Options

A Life Orb set can be viable because it doesn't require any setup and excels at wallbreaking, but it lacks the Speed provided by Agility or Choice Scarf. Rock Slide can be used on either set in conjunction with Sheer Force; however, this isn't very practical due to Rock Slide being the only notable physical move that Sheer Force benefits from. If you do decide to use Sheer Force and Rock Slide, replace Return with Body Slam for the additional power. X-Scissor is a nice coverage move, but most of the Grass-type Pokemon in Little Cup are hit neutrally by Bug-type attacks due to their secondary typing.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Krabby is walled by all of the common Grass-types in Little Cup, notably Cottonee, which can Encore Krabby's boosting moves, and Ferroseed, which is incredibly difficult for Krabby to break through, even with Superpower.

Electric-types: Electric-types, particularly Chinchou due to its Water-type resistance, can OHKO Krabby with a STAB move. Magnemite can also switch into any move but Knock Off, providing it still has Sturdy intact.

Status: Status moves also severely hinder Krabby's capabilities as a sweeper and wallbreaker. Burn and paralysis cripple it and even Toxic damage can be bothersome when trying to set up two moves and then sweep.

Frillish and Slowpoke: Frillish and Slowpoke are fantastic counters to any Krabby not running Knock Off, and they can easily burn it or paralyze it, respectively.

Croagunk: Croagunk can switch into anything, only taking neutral damage from Return or Body Slam.

sets.name: Boosting Sweeper
sets.description:
Moves

After an Agility, Krabby can outspeed every unboosted Pokemon in the tier as well as common Choice Scarf users. Crabhammer is Krabby's only physical STAB move and hits everything that doesn't resist it for a solid chunk of damage, while its only downside is the 90% accuracy. Knock Off can be used to cripple opposing walls and hit Slowpoke, Frillish, and Ferroseed, while Return has more Base Power and can hit anything, with the exception of Rock- and Steel-types. Hyper Cutter is the preferred ability, as it allows Krabby to break through Snubbull and switch into a nicely predicted Memento unscathed.

Set Details

The given EVs allow Krabby to outspeed most common Choice Scarf users after an Agility, and while 116 Speed can be beneficial to outspeed Choice Scarf Mienfoo and Chinchou, bulk is generally better. 12 Speed, after an Agility boost, lets Krabby outspeed the common Shell Smash Tirtouga. Eviolite is the preferred item so that Krabby can set up on opposing Pokemon that could otherwise threaten it with an OHKO; however, Berry Juice can be used against weaker Pokemon to ensure some recovery. If you decide to use Berry Juice, keep in mind that Krabby will most likely get KOed by many special moves, especially super effective ones, rendering the item useless. An Adamant nature gives Krabby more power, and there are no notable Pokemon that can hit 30 Speed and threaten Krabby.

Usage Tips

Switch into something that Krabby can reliably check and proceed to set up either Swords Dance or Agility as they switch out. Swords Dance allows Krabby to power through walls with ease, while Agility is more useful for dealing with faster threats. Krabby is most successful when the opponent's major priority users and bulky Grass-types have fainted, as Krabby lacks priority moves itself and has no reliable way to hit Pokemon such as Foongus and Ferroseed.

Team options

Krabby really appreciates entry hazard support so that can it power through bulkier Pokemon. It also appreciates Defog or Rapid Spin support so that it can reliably take a hit while setting up. Grass-type Pokemon make great partners due to their key resistances to Electric- and Grass-type attacks aimed at Krabby; Ferroseed is a notable choice because it can also lay down hazard support. Chinchou can also absorb Electric-type attacks, while Sap Sipper users, such as Deerling and Skiddo, can benefit from Grass-type attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Moves

Crabhammer is Krabby's main STAB move and is usually the prime option when revenge killing an opponent's Pokemon. Knock Off allows Krabby to severely cripple bulky Pokemon. Superpower is Krabby's best option to deal with Pawniard and Ferroseed, which can hit it hard and remove its Choice Scarf or otherwise completely wall it, respectively. Return is a nice, neutral-coverage move, and without it, Krabby is walled by Dry Skin Croagunk.

Set Details

These EVs allow Krabby to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and revenge kill successfully. An Adamant nature can be used if you crave more power, but this causes Krabby to Speed tie with a lot of common threats. A Jolly nature will outspeed common Choice Scarf Pokemon and Scraggy after a Dragon Dance, but you forgo the added power which can make a big difference when it comes to KOing an opposing Pokemon.

Usage Tips

Krabby is a great revenge killer and is best utilized in the mid- and late-game once the opponent's team is weakened, so it is guaranteed some KOs and does not have to worry about retaliation. Unfortunately, Krabby has no priority moves, so removing priority users before attempt to KO or sweep is a must. Krabby also lacks a pivot move, such as U-turn, and an item-switching move, such as Trick, which many other Choice Scarf users have access to, making it even more important that Krabby is used as a revenge killer or to clean up in the late-game. Also, do not switch into any special moves, especially Grass- and Electric-type attacks, because Krabby has a subpar Special Defense stat and an average HP stat and will likely be OHKOed.

Team Options

Krabby appreciates hazard support as it makes it easier to power through bulkier Pokemon. Defog or Rapid Spin support is also really helpful, as it helps Krabby retain HP so that it can take a hit while setting up. Grass-type Pokemon make great partners due to their key resistances to Electric- and Grass-type attacks; Ferroseed is especially notable, because it can also provide hazard support. Chinchou can also absorb Electric-type attacks. Krabby also benefits from a teammate that can handle common priority users, such as Fletchling and Spritzee, as priority can interfere with its sweeping.

Voltorb.overview: Voltorb is a unique Pokemon, though it is really only useful for its high Speed. It has quite a shallow movepool, but has enough moves to work well in several roles, but the only role in which it truly shines is as a Taunt user. Whenever you see Voltorb, which is not exceedingly often, it will likely run Taunt. Voltorb is quite frail. However, it shouldn't need to take many hits because it can revenge kill almost the entire metagame, thanks to its workable Special Attack which lets it run offensive sets as well as support sets, though these are less viable because Elekid outclasses Voltorb in every aspect but Speed. It can be devastating with a Life Orb. Voltorb's three abilities are all very interesting and varied. All in all, Voltorb can be a potent status user or an attacker that pulls its weight, but prospective users should be wary of its flaws.
Voltorb.comments:
Other Options

Voltorb could try to run Hidden Powers besides Ice to get coverage on Steel-types, but Hidden Power Ice is generally superior. Charge Beam is a nice way for Voltorb to increase its Special Attack, and can do significant damage after a few boosts. A set built around the use of the move would be interesting and unexpected, but might be difficult to pull off. Sucker Punch is an acceptable answer to Choice Scarf users that might outspeed Voltorb.

Many different items can be used effectively with Voltorb, notably Air Balloon and Choice Specs. Voltorb can also run Thief effectively due to its high base Speed. A set featuring Substitute and Berry Juice can be very effective. Light Screen is always a useful option for a lead that can learn it, and Voltorb appreciates the boost to Special Defense.

Checks and Counters

Choice Scarf Users: With its high Speed and low defenses, Voltorb badly wants to outspeed its opponents, but many foes are faster when they equip a Choice Scarf. Voltorb could carry Protect to scout for this. Voltorb must be especially wary of Ground-type Choice Scarf users.

Special Walls: Voltorb can't handle anything that can stomach an attack from it. This includes Chinchou and anything else that resists Ice-type attacks and is neutral to Electric-type attacks. Lileep is also a powerful check to Voltorb.

Ground-types: Voltorb's only true counters besides Chinchou are Ground-types. Voltorb has such a hard time dealing with them, especially on the lead set, that it's generally a good idea to support Voltorb with Shellder or another strong Ice-, Water-, or Grass-type to assist it. Once those are eliminated, Voltorb has almost no hope against Ground-types. Its Hidden Power Ice can provide only fleeting coverage.

sets.name: Lead
sets.description:
Moves

Rain Dance ensures weather due to Voltorb's extremely high Speed. It also makes Thunder, Voltorb's best attack, 100% accurate. Thunder is deadly under rain. However, it's too unreliable to be used without rain, so be sure to have Rain Dance up before you use the move. Volt Switch is an effective switching move, especially when coupled with STAB. It is useful in many situations and can to ensure Voltorb's survival in tight spots. Taunt is a good choice to counter the opponent's lead and status Pokemon, and can also stop boosting sweepers in their tracks. It is especially useful against entry hazard users such as Dwebble, as well as being Voltorb's only real niche over Elekid. However, it's next to useless against anything else and Thunder Wave can be used instead.

Set Details

Static is a useful ability in any situation, and offers a decent paralysis chance and that can cripple enemies. Aftermath can be equally useful by damaging defensive checks to Voltorb that manage to knock it out. Item-wise, a Damp Rock is almost mandatory for anything running Rain Dance. Eviolite should be used to bolster Voltorb's pitiful defenses in lieu of rain. The latter item prevents many OHKOs, notably from Choice Scarf users such as Pawniard and Mienfoo. The given EV spread allows Voltorb to deal significant damage and, with a Timid nature, to outspeed almost the entire metagame.

Usage Tips

This set is useful as a support lead and can deal serious damage to boot. Use the Rain Dance variant on rain teams as a Rain Dance user and a rain sweeper. The Eviolite variant is an excellent status lead on any team. Voltorb's tremendous Speed allows it to revenge kill quite a few Pokemon, as well as to outspeed and KO some other common leads.

Team Options

This set can't run Hidden Power Ice, so an Ice- or Grass-type is welcome to deal with Ground-types. Grass also resists Electric, so a Fire- or Flying-type helps as well. Even a Bug-type might be helpful, and might also be used to counter the many Psychic-type special walls that check this set. Of course, anything with an ability boosted by rain also benefits from this set.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Moves

Taunt is one of Voltorb's niches and is always an extremely useful move in LC. It's also the only thing offensive Voltorb has on Elekid. Thunderbolt is Voltorb's only reliable high Base Power STAB special attack, and is Voltorb's main means of sweeping. It will deal a sizable chunk of damage to many Pokemon with a Life Orb. Hidden Power Ice is Voltorb's source of coverage on the two types that resist Electric: Ground and Grass. It's moderately powerful with the boosting items that can be used with this set.

Set Details

Static is a powerful ability that can provide Voltorb with the capability to spread paralysis even with only offensive moves. Aftermath can be quite nice as well, making a revenge kill by a teammate much more likely. Life Orb increases Voltorb's damage output. HP IVs are reduced to 1 in order to limit Life Orb recoil while maintaining Hidden Power Ice. The same EV spread as used on the first set is advised here, and it is equally useful because it allows Voltorb to outspeed and OHKO or 2HKO most of the metagame. Timid allows Voltorb to hit 20 Speed and outrun almost every other unboosted Pokemon.

Usage Tips

Voltorb is an effective attacker and one of very few decent Electric-types in LC. It can be used as a special attacker on any team needing some Electric-type coverage. The Choice Specs variant of this set can be used as a powerful pivot, and with the right switching, pairs well with a different Life Orb user such as Abra. Feel free to attach a Choice Scarf to this set as well, as it allows Voltorb to outspeed the entirety of LC, even other Choice Scarf users.

Team Options

Some defensive allies, like such as Tirtouga and Koffing, are helpful to this set. Voltorb's pitiful defenses need some backup. Attackers to counter Rock- and Steel-types are also welcome, because this set can't handle those very well. For the Life Orb set, something with U-turn to build a VoltTurn core is useful. As mentioned previously, Abra is also very useful.

Exeggcute.overview: Exeggcute's unique Grass / Psychic typing is both a blessing and a curse, granting it seven weaknesses and six resistances. Harvest and Chlorophyll are great abilities that work well on sun-based teams, and the sun also grants Exeggcute recovery options that allow it to fill a niche in Little Cup. It has also good Defense and Special Attack, allowing it to function offensively and defensively. Exeggcute does have several limitations, however. It is beaten by the ever-present Knock Off and U-turn, its lackluster Speed and Special Defense leave it prey for most special attackers, and it is somewhat outclassed by Pokemon such as Trubbish and Cottonee because they have more reliable recovery.
Exeggcute.comments:
Other Options

Exeggcute has several other viable options, but typically they are outclassed or just ineffective. It can utilize a Chlorophyll set, but is generally outclassed by Pokemon like Deerling, Bulbasaur, and Bellsprout. Sludge Bomb is a way to deal with Cottonee and Spritzee. Synthesis can provide a quick and easy way to regain HP, but Exeggcute has so many other recovery options that it is not worth the turn or moveslot. Toxic can wear down other Pokemon faster in the long run than Leech Seed, but doesn't provide the recovery that Leech Seed does. Stun Spore can cripple foes for the match, but doesn't give Exeggcute a chance to immediately set up properly like Sleep Powder. Starf Berry can be run over Oran Berry on the Harvest set to boost repeatedly and turn Exeggcute into a formidable sweeper on its own, but if you don't get the right stat boosts all the effort will be a waste. Similarly, Lum Berry can be used with Rest to provide instant full recovery in a single turn multiple times, but this gives the opponent the opportunity to bring in a check when Exeggcute could have just set up a Substitute or used Sleep Powder instead. Leaf Storm can be run as a harder hitting attack, but the Special Attack decrease afterwards is not appreciated. Explosion can be used in conjunction with Trick Room to bring in a Trick Room sweeper unscathed, but like all Trick Room setters it should only be used on a dedicated Trick Room team. Lastly, dual screens can be set up reliably due to Exeggcute's high Defense.

Checks and Counters

Vullaby: Vullaby is immune to Sleep Powder, resists both of Exeggcute's STAB moves, takes nothing from Hidden Power Fighting, and hits back super effectively with STAB Knock Off.

Dark-types: Pokemon like Houndour, Vullaby, and Pawniard all take little to no damage from Giga Drain, and are immune to Psychic. They force a switch or KO with most of their moves, while Exeggcute is virtually helpless without Hidden Power Fighting. Houndour also has access to Early Bird which allows it to wake up faster and KO quickly with a STAB move.

Knock Off: Not only is Knock Off super effective against Exeggcute, it also permanently gets rid of the Oran Berry that makes Harvest, and by extension Exeggcute, usable.

Flying-types: Flying-types such as Fletchling, Archen, and Doduo can KO with STAB Acrobatics or Brave Bird, but must beware of taking damage on the switch from Psychic.

Fire-types: Fire-types such as Houndour, Ponyta, and Larvesta can take advantage of the sun that is set up for Exeggcute, and can usually OHKO with a STAB move.

Bug-types: Any Bug-type will most likely KO Exeggcute due to its 4x weakness. Exeggcute also fears U-turn, a common pivot move on Pokemon like Mienfoo, Bunnelby, and Larvesta.

Ghost-types: Ghost-types like Pumpkaboo can come in on Exeggcute and then use Substitute to avoid Leech Seed and Sleep Powder. They can then proceed to set up, or just KO with a STAB Shadow Ball.

Grass-types: Without Hidden Power Fire, Grass-types wall Exeggcute, as they can't be put to sleep or Leech Seeded, and Exeggcute cannot survive many super effective moves. However, Grass / Poison-types like Foongus and Bulbasaur should be wary of Psychic.

Sound-based Moves and Infiltrator: Though they are rare, moves that go through Substitute, such as Noibat's Air Slash or Hurricane, Zubat's Brave Bird or U-turn, and Joltik's Bug Buzz, hurt a lot.

sets.name: Harvest Abuser
sets.description:
Moves

Substitute lets Exeggcute safely abuse Harvest, giving it a nearly-unlimited supply of Oran Berries. Sleep Powder allows a free Substitute and also disables a single Pokemon for a short period of time. Predicting a switch is also a good opportunity to use Sleep Powder, set up a Substitute and attack, or set up a Leech Seed. Alternatively, Leech Seed can be used to wear down walls and provide even more recovery on top of Oran Berry and Giga Drain. Giga Drain provides a way of dealing damage while also providing some recovery, and is the primary STAB attack. Psychic is the secondary STAB move and can deal reliable damage to Fighting- and Poison-types that may want to use Knock Off, U-turn, or a Poison-type move. Hidden Power Fighting or Hidden Power Fire can be used to hit Pawniard and other Steel-types on the switch or while behind a Substitute, as otherwise these Pokemon can effortlessly switch in and OHKO Exeggcute with Knock Off. Additonally, Hidden Power Fire hits Bug- and Grass-types for super effective damage, preventing Ferroseed from walling Exeggcute. Protect is another option, but should only be used in conjunction with Leech Seed to safely restore more HP.

Set Details

The Speed EVs allow Exeggcute to Speed tie with Tirtouga before a Shell Smash. The 80 Special Defense EVs boost Exeggcute's poor Special Defense, giving it some much needed bulk. The rest of the EVs are dumped into Defense and Special Attack to bolster its two best stats. The combination of Harvest and Oran Berry gives Exeggcute unlimited recovery as long as it isn't hit with a move that can KO it while a Substitute isn't up.

Usage Tips

Exeggcute needs sun to function effectively, as sunlight gives it a 100% chance of recovering its Oran Berry with Harvest. Exeggcute also appreciates a slow pivot, which allows it to get into battle unscathed. Exeggcute likes to set up Substitutes against Pokemon that typically cannot harm it, like Chinchou, and against Pokemon that are inclined to set up, like Tirtouga and Omanyte. Leech Seed is a great recovery option that can also force switches, and such switch turns should be used to set up Substitute. Leech Seed works well in tandem with Exeggcute's other recovery options, such as Giga Drain and Oran Berry with Protect.

Team Options

Sun support is necessary to abuse Harvest. Vulpix can provide that support with Drought and can take Bug- and Ice-type moves well, while Exeggcute takes Water- and Ground-type moves for Vulpix in return. Pokemon that can come in on Pawniard and absorb Knock Off are also great partners. Exeggcute appreciates Stealth Rock, so a hazard setter like Onix or Dwebble is a good teammate. Additionally, Dwebble has access to Spikes which can further aid in racking up chip damage.

Cubone.overview: When holding its signature item, Thick Club, Cubone reaches 28 Attack without a positive nature. This, paired up with its wide array of coverage, and its signature move Bonemerang, which allows Cubone to break through the opponent's Focus Sash, Substitute, and Sturdy, makes Cubone one of the strongest attackers in Little Cup. Cubone also has very good physical bulk without Eviolite. However, all these positive traits are balanced out because Cubone is very slow, doesn't have a very good ability, and it has low special bulk. Cubone also requires support from Sticky Web, Trick Room, or Baton Pass to work properly. Lastly, the presence of Knock Off heavily hinders Cubone's sweeping capabilities because it needs its item to truly shine. Regardless of all this, with a bit a bit of support, Cubone could become an excellent sweeper for your team.
Cubone.comments:
Other Options

Substitute or Swords Dance can replace Fire Punch. The former allows Cubone to take an incoming Will-O-Wisp, or Sucker Punch from Pawniard, while the latter gives Cubone even more power, ensuring its switch-ins don't survive a hit. If you're using either of these two options, it's recommended that you use Rock Slide for the third move slot for better coverage, and that you don't use these with Trick Room Cubone, as they will waste one of your sweeping turns. Bone Rush can be used over Bonemerang if you wish to beat Sturdy + Berry Juice users completely, although 2-3 hits from Bone Rush are always going to be weaker than 2 hits from Bonemerang, leaving this option outclassed. Earthquake can replace Bonemerang if you wish to have more accuracy, although you will forgo your ability to break through Substitute, Focus Sash, and Sturdy. Double-Edge can be used in conjunction with the ability Rock Head, replacing Fire Punch for a solid 120 Base Power move; unfortunately, this option lacks coverage. Cubone can use Stealth Rock, but you're better off using Cubone's great power and coverage.

Checks and Counters

Koffing: Koffing is immune to Cubone's STAB thanks to Levitate and can cripple Cubone with Will-O-Wisp.

Knock Off: If Cubone gets hit by Knock Off, it will lose its item, and thus its boosted Attack stat.

Aqua Jet Users: Aqua Jet from Life Orb Corphish can OHKO Cubone. Carvanha doesn't OHKO with Aqua Jet, but instead it can use Protect to nullify the Speed drop from Sticky Web and KO Cubone. Offensive Tirtouga can 2HKO with Aqua Jet but Cubone's use of Bonemerang means Tirtouga's going to be left at 1 HP after that, especially because +2 Aqua Jet only has a 6.3% chance to OHKO.

Strong Flying-types: Even though they can't switch in relatively safely because of Cubone's coverage, Flying-types can switch in without Sticky Web lowering their Speed. Doduo can do a number on Cubone with a Life Orb-boosted Brave Bird. Choice Specs Taillow can also take down Cubone with Boomburst.

Choice Scarf Users: One of the biggest unexpected threats to Cubone is Choice Scarf Chinchou, which outspeeds and OHKOes Cubone with its Water-type STAB moves, even if Sticky Web is active. Choice Scarf Darumaka, Bunnelby, and Amaura can simply annihilate Cubone with their STAB moves.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
Moves

Bonemerang is Cubone's STAB move of choice, breaking Focus Sash, Substitute, and besting Sturdy + Berry Juice users. Also, because of the damage rolls in Little Cup, it hits harder than Earthquake. For example, a Cubone using Earthquake might deal 16 damage 50% of the time and 18 damage the other 50% of the time, whereas Bonemerang will deal consistent damage of 9, meaning you'll be getting 18 damage most of the time, unlike with Earthquake. Knock Off rids Cubone's checks and counters of their Eviolites, so they will have a harder time switching in a second time. Rock Slide keeps Flying-types such as Fletchling, Archen, and Vullaby in check, although Thunder Punch also does this. Both of these moves have their own benefits; for instance, Rock Slide can OHKO Larvesta, while Thunder Punch can OHKO Mantyke. Fire Punch is used to hit Grass-types such as Cottonee, Chespin, and Ferroseed.

Set Details

The EV spread listed gives Cubone as high Attack as it can possibly have, hitting 28 Attack while holding Thick Club. The Defense EVs allow Cubone to take less damage from Fletchling's Acrobatics, so that Cubone can land a Thunder Punch or Rock Slide more consistently. The Speed EVs leave Cubone with 14 Speed, which means that while Sticky Web is active, Cubone will be able to outspeed the whole unboosted metagame. Cubone can also be used on Trick Room teams with a spread of 116 HP / 196 Atk / 76 Def / 116 SpD, a Brave nature, and 0 Speed IVs. With this spread, Cubone can switch into attacks more often.

Usage Tips

Cubone should avoid being hit by Knock Off, as it will instantly lose half of its sheer power. After Sticky Web is active, Cubone can be switched in on resisted hits or attacks it's immune to and begin to sweep. The big difference for teams using Cubone in Trick Room is that Cubone has limited turns to sweep; however, because it's bulkier, it's able to take strong attacks such as Abra's Psychic, Chinchou's Scald, Bunnelby's Return, and Corphish's Life Orb-boosted Aqua Jet. Due to this, Cubone is able to switch into most non-resisted hits and begin its sweep. Even without support from Sticky Web, Baton Pass, or Trick Room, it can often only switch into slow walls, but Cubone's power can force the opponent to switch out, allowing you to weaken their team.

Team Options

Either Surskit or Spinarak would be the first partners to look at, as they're the best Sticky Web users in the metagame. Croagunk is able to beat Corphish and Carvanha, which threaten Cubone with Aqua Jet, making it a solid partner. Drilbur and Psychic-types such as Abra and Gothita can KO Koffing, which also poses a threat for Cubone. Baton Passers such as Torchic may be used as partners to pass Speed boosts to Cubone. Pokemon that spread paralysis around the opposing team, such as Cottonee and Porygon, allow Cubone to outspeed the opposing team later on. For Trick Room, bulky Trick Room users such as Porygon and Spritzee make for good partners, as they don't share a weakness with Cubone.

Lickitung.overview: Lickitung is one of the bulkiest Pokemon in Little Cup, having 90 / 75 / 75 defenses.
